State Key Laboratory of Heavy Oil Processing China University of Petroleum (Beijing) 18 Fuxue Road Beijing 102249 China Graphical abstract To elucidate the function of the metal Co in the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) process, a closed cycle mechanism, including generation/regeneration of sulfur vacancy, adsorption of thiophene and complete HDS reaction of thiophene (hydrogenation (HYD) and direct desulfurization (DDS) pathways), was investigated via density functional theory (DFT-D) calculations on pure MoS2 and Co-MoS2 catalysts. All possible products were taken into consideration; for example, both HYD and DDS pathways could produce four kinds of products (butadiene, 1-butene, 2-butene, and butane), while the HYD pathway on the S edge of 100% Co-MoS2 catalyst produced three of the same products without butane. From the functional analysis of Co, the Co promoter has changed the original reaction mechanism and related product distribution. The sulfur vacancy on the 50% Co-promoted S edge exhibited the most commendable HDS activity, and 2-butene is obviously improved. Whereas 50% of the Co-promoted Mo edge inhibits the HDS process, Co-doping in the Mo edge could limit its catalysis performance. The generation/regeneration of sulfur vacancies could be the rate-limiting step on the S edge of nonpromoted and Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts; however, it will not be the rate-limiting step on the Mo edge. Keywords HDS mechanism Co-promoter MoS2 catalyst HYD pathway DDS pathway 1 Introduction With the increasing demand for environmental protection, sulfur-containing compounds in transportation fuels, such as gasoline and diesel, are severely regulated by various organizations and governments [1–5]. Therefore, clean gasoline production has been recognized as a great national strategic demand. As the most widely applied technology in industry, hydrodesulfurization (HDS) technology [6–11] could effectively remove sulfides and produce qualified clean gasoline at low cost with steady performance. Therefore, the design and optimization of high-activity catalysts for HDS have garnered much interest. The approaches used to improve the catalytic activity mainly include synthesizing novel supports [12,13], adding chelating agents [14–16], and doping metal promoters [17,18]. For doping metal promoters, most studies have added transition metals [19,20] to the original MoS2 catalyst for tuning the interaction between the active constituent and supporter, which is beneficial for the formation of active selective catalysis sites. Different additive metals have different effects on catalysts. For example, Orita et al. [23] used density functional theory (DFT) to calculate the adsorption energy of thiophene on Mo16S32 cluster models with different promoter metal (Cr, Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, and Zn) doping. The results were then compared with the HDS activity of X-promoted MoS2 catalysts (X represents different promoter metals) obtained in previous experiments [24] to produce a volcano curve revealing the relationship between HDS activity of X/MoS2 catalysts and the adsorption energy of thiophene on X/MoS2 catalysts. The volcano curve indicates Co and Ni are the ideal promoters because of the mezzo adsorption energy of thiophene on both metals. In addition, Co-Mo and Ni-Mo systems are widely applied [25,26] in industry, such as Prime-G+ technology [27,28] and SCANFining technology [29]. The Co-Mo system showed stronger adsorption of thiophene and 1-butene than the Ni-Mo system [30]. Hatanaka et al. [31] reported that Co could improve catalysis activity and selectivity of removing thiophene due to the greater disintegrating of the C–S bond than the CC bond. Meanwhile, it was worth noting that the Co-Mo system had outstanding durability in regards to high temperature. Therefore, this work focuses on Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts. Kasztelan et al. [32] investigated the structure-activity relationship of the metal morphology and found that not only the type of added metals but also the doping amount could affect the performance of catalysts. Based on STM experimental researches [33–35], the doped Co(Ni) was observed on the edge site and the morphology also could be changed in the different reductive conditions, which provided the basis to build catalysis models in DFT calculations. Inamura et al. [36] reported that when the ratio of Co/(Co + Mo) was lower than 0.08, Co preferred to dope onto the edge of the MoS2 catalyst; however, Palcheva et al. [37] found that the Co-MoS2 catalyst possessed remarkable HDS catalytic activity with the Co/Mo ratio of 0.27. Jacquin et al. [38] pointed out that the optimal ratio of Co/Mo would dramatically improve the thiophene-removing efficiency, whereas the high ratio of Co/Mo ratio would lead to inhibitory behavior. Although the effect of the amount of Co on desulfurization has received considerable attention, the optimal ratio of Co/Mo has not reached a consensus. Additionally, the function or influence of Mo and S edges with different doping amounts of Co on the reaction pathway has been rarely reported [39]. In addition, people pay much attention to the study of the HDS mechanism because the understanding of hydrogenation and desulfurization on the molecular level could directly assist the design and improvement of HDS catalysts. Based on current studies, there are two basic HDS reaction routes which have been well accepted [40,41]: direct desulfurization (DDS) and hydrogenation (HYD) followed by sulfur removal. The benzothiophene and dibenzothiophene tend to be removed by the DDS pathway, where the first step is C–S bond scission, while 4,6-DMDBT prefers the HYD pathway, in which the C–S bond breaks just after hydrogenation because of the steric hindrance originating from the alkyl substituents [42]. Based on previous experimental research [43–45], there are three possible intermediates (2,3-DHT, 2,5-DHT, and THT) and four possible products (1-butene, 2-butene, butadiene, and butane) in the thiophene HDS process. However, current experimental studies [4,21,46–50] about the HDS mechanism hardly solve the detailed fundamental problems because of the existing limitations of characterization methods, such as the elementary steps, including the generation of intermediates and products in the HDS process that are difficult to determine. Therefore, the theoretical method has been widely adopted as a tool to thoroughly describe the reaction pathways from the molecular level, which has helped us recognize the promoted active phase and nanocrystallite morphologies [51,52]. It was proposed that Co preferred to dope in the S edge for typical HDS conditions [46,53] as well. While from the molecular level, the previous studies on the thiophene HDS mechanism are not sufficient. Yao et al. [54] studied the thiophene HDS mechanism on a Mo3S9 model catalyst by DFT calculation and concluded that 2,5-Dihydrothiophene (2,5-DHT) is the important intermediate according to calculated energy data. Moses et al. [40] researched the thiophene HDS mechanism on a periodic MoS2 catalyst model by calculating the HYD pathway with 2,5-DHT as an intermediate and one of DDS pathways to form 2-butene over a pure MoS2 catalyst. However, the paths about other widely accepted intermediates (2,3-DHT and THT) [43] were not mentioned in the above reports. In addition, some paths, including the formation of 1-butene, butadiene, and butane still remain indeterminate. Recently, Zheng et al. [41] have investigated and summarized more complicated and complete HYD and DDS pathways; however, some products involved in the reaction network still need to be supplemented. In addition, it should be noted that almost all researches focused on the reaction mechanism on the pure MoS2 catalyst. To the best of our knowledge, the thiophene HDS reaction mechanism over a Co-doping MoS2 catalyst was only reported by Moses et al. [39]. They calculated 100% Co-doping on S edge of MoS2 catalyst and found that doping Co increased the hydrogenation activity but prevented CS bond breakage. Therefore, it is essential to further investigate this process. Before investigating the HDS process, the generation/regeneration of sulfur vacancy, which is suggested as an active site for the HDS reaction, is also calculated to close the reaction cycle. Prodhomme et al. [55] researched various generation paths of sulfur vacancy on the Mo and S edges of MoS2 catalysts, which provides the important mechanisms for calculating the formation of sulfur vacancies. The active site could affect the adsorption mode as proposed by theoretical and microscopy research [34,56,57]. Above all, in order to reveal the influence of the Co-doping amount on the thiophene HDS reaction mechanism, this paper studies complete thiophene HDS reaction mechanism, including five HYD pathways involving three intermediates (2,3-DHT, 2,5-DHT, and THT) [43] and four possible products (1-butene, 2-butene, butadiene, and butane) [45], as well as four DDS pathways with all four possible products (1-butene, 2-butene, butadiene, and butane) over pure MoS2, 50% and 100% Co-doped MoS2 catalysts. The generation/regeneration of the sulfur vacancy and adsorption configurations of thiophene over both the S edge and the Mo edge of pure MoS2 and 50% and 100% Co-MoS2 are discussed as well. Therefore, based on the reaction barriers of every elementary step of each path, the preferred reaction paths and products could be obtained; furthermore, the role of Co promoters and different quantities are discussed and determined. 2 Computational details The MoS2 (10-10) surface was periodically represented as S-Mo-S slabs with 4 Mo rows in the x-direction and 4 Mo rows in the y-direction; the bottom two layers are constrained at the positions, and the upper two layers are relaxed in the calculations [58]. Both the Mo edge and the S edge of the MoS2 catalyst (Fig. 1 ) exists under realistic reaction conditions and can reach stable structures by sulfur reconstruction [35,59–62]. Meanwhile, active sites are generated when sulfur was reconstructed to form an S vacancy. The Mo edge covered by 50% sulfur and the S edge covered by 100% sulfur are considered as stable structures under high H2 content [63,64]. After considering S vacancy, the Mo edge of stable MoS2 has 37.5% sulfur coverage, and the S edge has 87.5% sulfur coverage. For the structures of Co-doped MoS2 catalysts, theoretical studies [46,52,53] showed that a 50% Co promoter is easy to obtain both on the Mo edge and the S edge, but a 100% Co promoter prefers to generate on the S edge. Based on work by Krebs et al. [52] to obtain most stable structures, the Mo edge and S edge of 50% Co-doped MoS2 catalysts have 25% sulfur coverage and 62.5% sulfur coverage, respectively, and the S edge of the 100% Co-doped MoS2 catalysts is covered by 50% sulfur. To avoid interaction between adjacent slabs, a 15 Å vacuum is set in each model. The five structures underwent geometry optimization are shown in Fig. 2 . For simplicity, the Mo edge and S edge with sulfur vacancies of the pure MoS2 catalyst are denoted as T1 and T2, respectively, the Mo edge and S edge of the 50% Co-MoS2 catalyst are recorded as T3 and T4, respectively, and T5 represents the S edge of 100% Co-MoS2. In addition, before considering the generation/regeneration of sulfur vacancies, the Mo and S edge models of nonpromoted and Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts are listed in Fig. 3 . Density fundamental theory (DFT) calculations were performed by the Dmol3 program in the Material Studio Package. The generalized gradient approach with a function developed by Perdew, Burke and Ernzerhof (GGA-PBE) was applied [37,65]. Additionally, the Grimme method was adopted for dispersion corrections (DFT-D). The double-numerical plus polarization functional (DNP) and DFT semicore pseudopotentials (DSPPs) were employed [66,67]. A Monkhorst-Pack mesh k-point f (4 × 4 × 2) was adopted. SCF tolerance was 1.0 × 10−6 Ha and uses DIIS to accelerate the process. The spin was unrestricted and formal spin was used as the initial parameter. Additionally, convergence tolerances energy, maximum force, maximum displacement, maximum iterations and maximum step size are 1.0 × 10-5 Ha, 0.002 Ha/ Å, 0.005 Å, 1000 and 0.3 Å, respectively. For the orbital occupancy, smearing was used with a value of 0.002 Å, and the global orbital cutoff is 4.9 Å. Transition state (TS) searches were carried out at the same level with the Linear Synchronous Transit (LST)/Quadratic Synchronous Transit (QST) methods [68]. In this method, the energy maximum along the LST pathway was searched using the reactant and product energy points, followed by a conjugate gradient optimization of this configuration that was used to perform QST maximization. After that, another conjugated gradient minimization was performed. Such a cycle would proceed until the calculation was converged. Each transition state searched can be verified with a single imaginary frequency [69], and partial imaginary frequencies listed in Supporting information. The adsorption energy (Eads) is defined as the difference between the total energy of the interacting (adsorbate + surface) system and the isolated states as shown in Eq. (1). (1) E a d s = E ( a d s + s l a b ) - E a d s - E s l a b E (ads + slab) is the energy of the surface including the adsorbate, E (slab) means to the energy of the clean surface and E (ads) represents the energy of adsorbate at isolated states. Based on the equation, the negative value of Eads indicates that it is an exothermic adsorption, and the largest value means to the most stable adsorption configuration. The reaction barrier (Ea) and reaction energy (Er) are calculated by Eqs. (2) and (3), respectively. (2) E a = E T S - E R (3) E r = E P - E R ETS, ER and EP represent the energy of the transition state (TS) reactant and product system, respectively. 3 Results From the atomic scale, the whole thiophene-removing process on MoS2-based catalysts could be divided into four steps (shown in Fig. 4 ), sulfur vacancy generation, i.e., CUS (coordinately unsaturated sites); sulfide adsorption; HDS; and regeneration of sulfur vacancy. The scheme of the HDS process is shown in Fig. 5 , (a) In the HYD pathway, thiophene could take place two hydrogenation steps to form 2,3-DHT or 2,5-DHT, then, 2,3-DHT breaks two C–S bonds to obtain 1-butene, 2,5-DHT could generate 1-butene, 2-butene, or butadiene by C–S bond scissions. Besides, both 2,3-DHT and 2,5-DHT could continue to hydrogenate to form THT, and then, it transfer to butane by C–S bond scissions; (b) In the DDS pathway, thiophene directly take place first C–S bond scission to form CH2CHCHCHS (butadienethiolate), then, it could continue to break the second C–S bond to form butadiene, or it carries out different degrees hydrogenation, at last, it occurs second C–S bond scission to generate 2-butene, 1-butene, or butane. In this work, the four steps were calculated on five catalysis surfaces (T1, T2, T3, T4, and T5). The calculated results of the steps will be described in the following four sections in succession. 3.1 Generation of sulfur vacancies (CUS) As is known, CUS are the active sites responsible for adsorbing sulfide with unoccupied d-states [70,71] and then carrying out the HDS process. For nonpromoted MoS2 catalysts, it is a stable configuration with 50% S coverage on Mo edge and 100% S coverage on S edge under high p(H2) conditions, and there are no sulfur vacancies on both edges. To investigate the HDS process on the Mo edge and the S edge, sulfur vacancies were constructed through hydrogen removal of a sulfur on both edges, in spite of the proposal by Moses et al. [40] that the Mo edge allows for the addition of a S atom, which is carried out by the HDS process on brim sites of the Mo edge. By analyzing the formation of the sulfur vacancy process, after hydrogen dissociative adsorption, two hydrogen atoms transfer to form H2S adsorbing on the catalysis surface; finally, H2S desorbs to gas, so that a sulfur atom is removed to obtain a sulfur vacancy; the configurations shown in Fig. 3(a) and (b) change to the structures referred to in Fig. 2(a) and (b) (T1 and T2, which are active surfaces to achieve HDS). The process calculations are similar to those used in previous studies [41,55]. For example, Prodhomme et al. [55] investigated the formation of sulfur vacancies considering thermal and entropic corrections, various paths, and a variety of sulfur coverage. The structures and energy profiles are shown in the Supporting information. There are two paths to get sulfur vacancies on both the Mo edge and the S edge of nonpromoted MoS2 catalysts. The lower reaction barrier of the rate-limiting steps of each edge are listed in Table 1 . The lower reaction barrier of the rate-limiting steps of forming the sulfur vacancy process on the Mo edge is 0.71 eV and 1.66 eV on the S edge. In addition, the catalysis performance of Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts was also investigated in our work. In different industrial conditions, such as water-gas shift reaction, CO methanation reaction, and HDS reaction, there are still debates about the Co promoter preferring the Mo edge or S edge; some research shows the Co promoter is inclined to substitute Mo atoms of the S edge, whereas some studies support the Mo edge [51,35,62]. Moreover, the models of Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts including Co doped in the Mo edge and the S edge with different contents were also investigated in previous studies [52,53,72]. Considering the industrial HDS conditions, Krebs et al. [52] calculated the energy per edge metal atom of 50% and 100% Co-doping in the Mo and S edges with changes of p(H2S)/p(H2). There are similar energies for the 50% Co promoter substituting Mo atoms of both edges, which indicates that Co has a similar affinity for both edges; in contrast, the energy of the S edge with 100% Co is approximately 0.20 eV per edge metal atom lower than the Mo edge, which corresponds to previous research [53,72]. Therefore, the 50% Co promoter is doped in both the Mo edge and S edge, and the 100% Co promoter in the S edge is adopted as a catalysis model. Furthermore, based on calculations by Krebs et al. [52], the three models covered by 25%, 62.5%, and 50% sulfur are the most stable configurations (denoted as T3, T4, and T5, respectively, shown in Fig. 2). Compared to nonpromoted MoS2 catalysts, the Mo and S edges of Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts are formed with CUS and are reactive for thiophene without any advanced sulfur removal. Thus, T3, T4, and T5 are the active surfaces applied to the HDS process in succession. 3.2 Adsorption of thiophene on active surfaces As mentioned previously, T1 and T2 surfaces are the active surfaces for removal of sulfur from equilibrium structures of the Mo and S edges of nonpromoted MoS2 catalysts, respectively. T3, T4, and T5 are the equilibrium structures with active sites of the Mo edge and S edge with 50% Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts, and the S edge with 100% Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts, respectively. The active sites with electronic unoccupied d-states, which are clearly responsible for strong adsorption energies of electron-donation species such as sulfur atoms [70,71], are the adsorptive sites of thiophene. To investigatethe catalysis performance of MoS2-based catalysts and the reactive mechanism of thiophene, research about adsorption modes of thiophene is necessary. Therefore, based on DFT calculations, the stable adsorption configurations, adsorption energies, bond length, and bond angle are listed in the Supporting information Fig. S1 and Table S2. The results indicate that all stable adsorption sites of thiophene on five edges show S vacancies by η1 adsorption mode (binding through S atom), which is consistent with the conclusion that catalysts with a low number of CUS are more feasible for obtaining η1 adsorption mode [56], whereas a high number of CUS is inclined to form η5 adsorption mode [73]. 3.3 HDS process of thiophene on active surfaces Based on previous studies [39–41], we proposed more holonomic pathways of the thiophene HDS reaction, as shown in Fig. 5, which include three intermediates (2,3-DHT, 2,5-DHT, and THT) in the HYD pathway and four products (1-butene, butadiene, 2-butene, and butane) in both the HYD and DDS pathways; all the intermediates and products were reported in previous research [41,45]. Based on previous research [39], we think that the initial C–S scission or hydrogenation takes place in DHT (dihydrothiophene) after the addition of two hydrogen atoms in the HYD pathway. There are five HYD pathways, including 2,3-DHT as the intermediate to obtain 1-butene, 2,5-DHT as the intermediate to generate butadiene, 2-butene, and 1-butene, and THT as intermediate to form butane; the energy potential diagrams are shown in Figs. 6–10 . Although, the initial S-C scission occurs with the first hydrogenation in the DDS pathway. There are four paths with four products, and cis-butadienethiolate is indispensable to generate all four products; the energy potential diagrams are shown in Figs. 11–14 . In Figs. 6–14, typical situations are shown with the molecular formula below the abscissa representing the corresponding reactants and products, and the number above the abscissa indicates the corresponding reactions in Table 2 (HYD pathway) or Table 3 (DDS pathway). However, special cases exist. For example, in Fig. 6, the number “2″ below the black line (T1) means reaction 2 occurs, as listed in Table 2, in spite of the corresponding abscissa sites noted by number “1.″ In addition, the reaction barrier of rate-limiting step of each path is shown in the figures. Therefore, all paths of the HYD and DDS pathways are investigated on the five active surfaces (T1, T2, T3, T4, and T5). All the elementary steps involved in the HYD and DDS pathways are listed in Tables 2 and 3 with calculated reaction barriers and reaction energies, respectively. The structures of reactants, transition states, and products involved in elementary steps are exhibited in Section 3 of the Supporting information. 3.3.1 HYD pathway Figs. 6–10 show the energy profiles of five paths (2,3-DHT as intermediate to form 1-butene, 2,5-DHT as intermediate to generate butadiene, 2-butene, and 1-butene, and THT as intermediate to obtain butane) with notes of order number of elementary reactions corresponding to Table 2 on T1, T2, T3, T4, and T5 surfaces, respectively. All the structures of reactants, transition state, and products involved in elementary reactions are listed in Section 3 of the Supporting information. All the initial states of reaction are thiophene and a hydrogen atom adsorbed on the surfaces, except for the paths that occur on T2 surfaces with thiophene and two hydrogen atoms, which will not affect the results of reaction barriers and reaction energies. On the T1 surface, the adsorbed hydrogen atom transfers to carbon 3 to form 3-hydrothiophene-2-yl (reaction 2 in Table 2) and continues hydrogenation by the addition of another adsorbing hydrogen atom to form 2,3-DHT (reaction 5 in Table 2). The two hydrogenation steps are accompanied with reaction barriers 2.06 and 0.29 eV, respectively. If the hydrogen atom attacks carbon 2 instead of carbon 3 first, the intermediate of 2,5-DHT will be produced because the steric hindrance will inhibit H transfer to carbon 3. However, on the T2, T3, and T4 surfaces, the hydrogenation order to form 2,3-DHT is adding a hydrogen atom to carbon 2 to generate 2-hydrothiophene-3-yl initially (reaction 1 in Table 2). Next, the second hydrogen addition reaction takes place on carbon 3 (reaction 3 in Table 2). While on the T5 surface, it is unfavorable to form 2,3-DHT and THT because of the adsorption configuration with long distance from the co-adsorbed hydrogen atom to carbon 3. Similarly, previous research [39] only reported paths with 2,5-DHT as the intermediate to the HYD pathway on 100% Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts. Subsequently, C–S scissions with hydrogenation will take place as reactions 11 and 12 in Table 2, on T1, T2, T3, and T4 surfaces, to generate 1-butene after 2,3-DHT formation. Exceptionally, the blue line (T2 surface) in Fig. 6 shows some differences in that reaction 12 is divided to two steps, hydrogenation and 1-butene desorption with C–S scission. The reaction barrier rate-limiting steps of this path on T1, T2, T3, and T4 surfaces are 2.06, 1.79, 1.58, and 2.25 eV, respectively, and the rate-limiting step on T1 is the hydrogenation reaction, whereas it is the C–S cleavage on other surfaces. Comparing the path with 2,3-DHT as the intermediate, the first hydrogen addition reaction of the HYD pathway proceeding via 2,5-DHT on the T2, T3, and T4 surfaces is reaction 1 in Table 2, while on the T1 surface, it is changed to reaction 1 from reaction 2. The second hydrogenation step is reaction 4 in Table 2. In succession, two C–S scissions (reaction 13 and 14 in Table 2) take place in order without hydrogen addition to form butadiene. However, if there are hydrogenation reactions accompanying with C–S bond breaking (reactions 15 and 16 in Table 2), 2-butene is generated. In addition, in the path to form 1-butene, a hydrogen atom transfers to carbon 2 of 2,5-DHT (reaction 8) on the T1, T2, T3, and T4 surfaces, thereby forming 2,3,5-trihydrothiophene-4-yl. Next, the bond between carbon 5 and sulfur is broken directly (reaction 17) with the formation of 1-butenethiol. In contrast, on the T5 surface, the bond between carbon 5 and sulfur is broken first (reaction 13), and then the hydrogen atom is added to carbon 3 (reaction 21). In the last elementary reaction, another C–S bond breaks with hydrogen attacking (reaction 18) on five surfaces. By analyzing the reaction barrier data, it could be found that all the rate-limiting steps of paths via 2,5-DHT are C–S scissions, except the path forming butadiene on nonpromoted MoS2 catalysts (T1 and T2 surfaces), which are same to the rate-limiting steps of producing 2,5-DHT. In the HYD pathway, after addition of two hydrogen atoms, hydrogenation could also take place to form another intermediate THT. On the T1 and T2 surfaces, THT is formed by hydrogenating 2,3-DHT (reaction 7 and 10) and by hydrogenating 2,5-DHT (reaction 8 and 9) on the T3 and T4 surfaces. Specially, the hydrogenation order of forming 2,3-DHT on T2 surface (reaction 1 and 3) is different than the T1 surface (reaction 2 and 5). Finally, the steps of butane formation are two C–S scissions with hydrogenation. The rate-limiting step of this path on T1 (2.09 eV) is a hydrogenation reaction, while the C–S scission is the rate-limiting step on the T2, T3, and T4 (2.09, 1.84, and 1.90 eV, respectively) surfaces. 3.3.2 DDS pathway On the DDS pathway, C–S bond cleavage is the first step of the thiophene HDS reaction with hydrogenation (reaction 1 in Table 3) to form cis-butadienethiolate. Different from the HYD pathway, all five surfaces have four paths. In addition, the DDS pathway has the same elementary reactions of the same reaction paths. In the first path, another C–S scission with hydrogenation occurs to get butadiene (reaction 2 in Table 3). The reaction barriers of the rate-limiting steps on five surfaces are 2.30, 2.31, 1.48, 1.71, and 1.69 eV, as shown in Fig. 11. In the second path, to form 2-butene, there are two hydrogen addition reactions (reaction 3 and 4 in Table 3) with cis-2-butenethiol forming prior to the second C–S scission (reaction 5). By comparing the reaction barriers of all elementary reactions, it could be concluded that the rate-limiting step on the T1, T2, T3, and T5 surfaces is C–S scission (reaction barriers are 1.23, 2.17, 2.00, and 1.47 eV, as shown in Fig. 12, respectively), whereas it is hydrogenation on the T4 surface with 0.84 eV, as shown in Fig. 12. Similarly, two hydrogenation reactions occur before C–S bond breaking (reaction 7); however, the second hydrogen addition takes place in carbon 3 (reaction 6) instead of carbon 5 (reaction 4) to obtain cis-3-butenethiolate. For this path, the highest reaction barriers are 0.92, 2.17, 2.02, 1.73, and 1.61 eV on the T1 to T5 surfaces, respectively (Fig. 13). In the last path, two continuous hydrogen addition steps are taken into consideration for the formation of butanethiolate from cis-3-butenethiolate, and then the C–S bond breaks with hydrogen attacking; butane is formed. The data in Table 3 indicate that this path on all surfaces has relatively high reaction barriers (1.88, 2.17, 2.02, 1.97, and 2.28 eV, as shown in Fig. 14), which indicates that butane is difficult to generate directly [41]. 3.4 Regeneration of sulfur vacancy (CUS) After the HDS process, the products were desorbed to leave the surfaces, while sulfur atoms remained on active sites resulting in inactivation of sulfur vacancy (CUS). Thus, T1 and T2 surfaces returned to equilibrium structures, and the regeneration process corresponded to the generation process, which is referred to in Section 3.1. In contrast, the regeneration of sulfur vacancy on the T3, T4, and T5 surfaces is calculated, the energy profiles and structures are shown in Section 4 of the Supporting information, and the highest reaction barriers of each surfaces are listed in Table 1. It is clear that the catalysis process of all five surfaces returns the surfaces to their initial states. 4 Discussions 4.1 Formation of active sites and adsorption of thiophene In our calculations, the rate limiting steps on the both Mo and S edges of nonpromoted MoS2 catalysts are the transformation of hydrogen atom to sulfur atom to form adsorbed H2S, and the reaction barriers of the rate-limiting steps are 0.71 and 1.66 eV. It could be concluded that the formation of sulfur vacancy is more feasible on the Mo edge than the S edge, which corresponds to previous studies [41,55]. For the Mo and S edges of 50% Co-promoted and the S edge of 100% Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts, the reaction barriers are 1.29, 1.64, and 1.69 eV, respectively. After 50% Co-doping, it is still more feasible on the Mo edge than the S edge to generate sulfur vacancy. Moreover, Co-doping would increase the difficulty of sulfur vacancy formation on the Mo edge, whereas little influence was seen on the S edge, which was different from the calculations in previous research [39]. We think the reason is the different mechanisms applied in two calculations. 4.2 HDS process on Mo and S edges Both HYD and DDS pathways could occur on the Mo and S edges; however, the most feasible paths are different, which results in different product selectivity. As introduced in Section 3.3, there are nine paths on the Mo and S edges of nonpromoted and 50% Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts. In the following section, the difficulty of paths and product selectivity will be analyzed to determine the different catalysis on Mo and S edges without considering intermediate transformation on the edges. Above all, on the T1 surface (Mo edge of nonpromoted MoS2 catalysts), the nine HYD and DDS pathways could be compared on the basis of Tables 2 and 3. Four paths are more favored to occur with a reaction barrier of the rate-limiting step less than 1.5 eV, and products include 1-butene, 2-butene, and butadiene, while butane is difficult to form [41]. They are the HYD pathways that generate 2-butene (1.33 eV) and butadiene (1.41 eV) by 2,5-DHT as intermediate and the DDS pathways that produce 1-butene (0.92 eV) and 2-butene (1.23 eV). Furthermore, if the generation of sulfur vacancy is considered, the rate-limiting steps will not change since lower barriers of sulfur vacancy form. From the view of products, only butadiene is obtained by the HYD pathway; all the other products (1-butene, 2-butene, and butane) are more likely generated by the DDS pathway. 1-butene will be the most prevalent product on the T1 surface after considering the two pathways together. On the T2 surface (S edge of nonpromoted MoS2 catalysts), the lowest reaction barrier of the rate-limiting step of the DDS pathway is 2.17 eV, even higher than the highest reaction barrier of the rate-limiting step of 2.15 eV on the T1 edge, and the dominate product on the T2 surface is butadiene with only a 1.15 eV reaction barrier by the 2,5-DHT as intermediate path of the HYD pathway. Additionally, if considering the generation of sulfur vacancy, the reaction barriers of these paths will increase to 1.66 eV (barrier of sulfur vacancy forming on the S edge of pure MoS2 catalysts), while it is still the most feasible path on the T2 surface. Furthermore, on the T3 surface (Mo edge of 50% Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts), due to the reaction barriers from high to low, the five paths of the HYD pathway could be sequenced as follows: 1-butene / 2,5-DHT (2.48 eV) > 2-butene / 2,5-DHT (2.00 eV) > butane / THT (1.84 eV) > butadiene / 2,5-DHT (1.71 eV) > 1-butene / 2,3-DHT (1.58 eV). From the view of products, the dominate product will be 1-butene by the HYD pathway. Similarly, the four paths of the DDS pathway could be determined in proper order based on the reaction barrier of rate-limiting step as follows: 1-butene (2.02 eV) = butane (2.02 eV) > 2-butene (2.00 eV) > butadiene (1.48 eV). Consequently, butadiene is the main product of the DDS pathway. Thus, butadiene and 1-butene are selected on the T3 surface. If considering the effect of regenerated sulfur vacancy, the lower barrier of the formed sulfur vacancy (1.29 eV) will not change the rate-limiting steps of all the paths on T3 surface. In addition, considering both the HYD and DDS pathways on the T4 surface (S edge of 50% Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts), we found that 2-butene (acquired by the HYD pathway overcoming the 0.65 eV reaction barrier and the DDS pathway with surmounting 0.84 eV), and butadiene (obtained mainly by the HYD pathway accompanied with the 0.85 eV reaction barrier) are the dominate products on the T4 surface. Obviously, it shows commendable performance of the HDS process. However, it is worth mention that when considering regeneration of sulfur vacancy, the lowest reaction barrier will increase to 1.64 eV (reaction barrier of rate-limiting step to regenerate sulfur vacancy on the T4 surface). Therefore, it could be concluded that the reaction shows different mechanisms on different edges. The reaction more often occurs along the HYD pathway on the S edge of the pure MoS2 catalyst, whereas the DDS pathway is more feasible on the Mo edge of the pure MoS2 catalyst, which matches results from a previous study [41]. Differently, both the HYD pathway and the DDS pathway could act similarly on Mo and S edges of 50% Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts. On the both nonpromoted and promoted MoS2 catalysts, the product selectivity is different between the Mo edge and the S edge. The product selectivity results from the influence of different active surfaces on detailed elementary steps. In general, both HYD and DDS pathways could be regarded as the combination of hydrogenation and C–S bond cleavages. Whether nonpromoted or with 50% Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts, the rate-limiting steps on both the Mo and S edges are mostly C–S scissions. On the Mo edge of pure MoS2, the rate-limiting steps of three paths are hydrogenation, only one path on the S edge of pure MoS2, and two paths on the Mo and S edges of 50% Co-promoted MoS2. Hence, the decrease of the C–S scission barriers will significantly promote the HDS process. Furthermore, in the DDS pathway, the C–S bond breaking of cis-2-butenethiolate is more feasible, while cis-3-butenethiolate is more unpopular on the S edge than the Mo edge, and it has similar degrees of difficulty for C–S bond scissions in cis-butadienethiolate and butanethiolate on both Mo and S edges. Therefore, the Mo edge and the S edge have different effects on different thiolate, and the important intermediates represent different paths with products, which indicates the difference of product selectivity between Mo and S edges. 4.3 The effect of Co-doping on Mo and S edges As mentioned previously, Mo and S edges have intrinsic distinctions, which affect catalysis performance. Furthermore, the promoter changes the nature of Mo or S edges and results in diversity between nonpromoted and promoted edges. In this work, the influence of Co promoters on HDS mechanisms is also investigated, which could provide theoretical support to design highly efficient Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts. Above all, by analyzing the effect of Co-doping on the Mo edge and compared with previous studies about all nine paths on the T1 edge, the Co promoter impacts the product distribution while the butane still is difficult to form. In addition, Co-doping also hinders all product formations on the Mo edge. These results indicate that the Co promoter inhibits catalysis activity of the Mo edge. Specially, the reaction barrier of the most feasible path on the Mo edge of 50% Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts (1.48 eV) is much higher than on nonpromoted MoS2 catalysts (0.92), even though considering the generation/regeneration of sulfur vacancy that will not be changed. Considering the HYD pathway and DDS pathway on the T4 edge together, we could find that 2-butene (formed by the HYD pathway with overcoming a 0.65 eV reaction barrier and the DDS pathway surmounting 0.84 eV) and butadiene (obtained mainly by the HYD pathway accompanied with a 0.85 eV reaction barrier) are the dominate products on the T4 edge. Meanwhile, the main product is butadiene, with a relatively high reaction barrier of 1.15 eV on the T2 edge. Obviously, the Co promoter is helpful to the HDS reaction on the S edge. However, after 100% Co-doping on the S edge, the products butadiene, 1-butene, 2-butene, and butane are inclined to generate reaction barriers of 1.42, 1.61, 1.47, and 2.28 eV, respectively. Except butane, the other products are generated with similar difficulty and rate. Therefore, with the S edge with 100% Co-doping, the products tend to distribute equally except butane; meanwhile, the lowest barrier of the rate-limiting step is the highest. Consequently, the 50% Co promoter on the S edge greatly promotes the formation of butadiene and 2-butene, whereas it only slightly impacts 1-butene and butane. The 100% Co promoter on the S edge contributes to 2-butene and 1-butene formation, while it inhibits butadiene and butane formation. The S edge of 50% Co-MoS2 catalyst has higher selectivity and activity than the S edge of 100% Co-MoS2 catalysts. However, after considering the generation/regeneration of sulfur vacancy, the S edge will be the rate-limiting step on the T2, T4, and T5 surfaces because of the higher reaction barrier of generation/regeneration of sulfur vacancy than the reaction barrier of the paths forming dominate products. It could be concluded that the generation/regeneration of sulfur vacancy will not affect the HDS process on the Mo edge, whereas it will be the rate-limiting step for more feasible paths on the S edge on nonpromoted or Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts. 5 Conclusion The closed cycles of MoS2-based catalysts catalyzing thiophene HDS process are considered in this work, including sulfur vacancy generation (CUS), thiophene adsorption, the HDS process, complete thiophene HDS reaction mechanisms of the HYD pathway (including all three possible intermediates) and the DDS pathway, including all possible direct products (butadiene, 1-butene, 2-butene, and butane)), and sulfur vacancy regeneration (CUS). Regarding the closed cycle, the following conclusions could be drawn: (1) Similar to sulfur generation promoted on nonpromoted MoS2 catalysts [41,55], with 50% Co-promotion, sulfur vacancy regeneration on the S edge is still more difficult than on the Mo edge; although, Co-doping inhibits it on the Mo edge. (2) Comparing the catalysis of the Mo edge and the S edge on the thiophene HDS process, which is nonpromoted, the Mo edge is more inclined to occur on the DDS pathway; the S edge is more suitable for the HYD pathway, which corresponds to previous research [41]. However, both the HYD pathway and the DDS pathway could occur on Mo and S edges of 50% Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts. (3) Co-doping changes the product selectivity, and the activity is also influenced significantly. For example: 1) On the nonpromoted Mo edge, the most feasible product is 1-butene overcoming 0.92 eV, after doping 50% Co, the dominant product is changed to butadiene overcoming 1.58 eV; 2) On the nonpromoted S edge, the dominant product is 2-butene with 1.15 eV reaction barrier, after doping 50% Co, the most feasible product is 2-butene with 0.65 eV reaction barrier. (4) Based on our calculations, 50% Co-doping will inhibit the HDS process on the Mo edge, while the sulfur vacancy on the S edge has commendable catalytic performance. In this work, only the catalysis performance of active sites on edges was considered. To comprehensively understand the effect of Co-doping in MoS2 catalysts, the catalysis process of active sites on the brim and corner will be studied. In addition, the influence of Co-doping on the amounts of active sites will also be considered. coredata.dc:description: To elucidate the function of the metal Co in the hydrodesulfurization (HDS) process, a closed cycle mechanism, including generation/regeneration of sulfur vacancy, adsorption of thiophene and complete HDS reaction of thiophene (hydrogenation (HYD) and direct desulfurization (DDS) pathways), was investigated via density functional theory (DFT-D) calculations on pure MoS2 and Co-MoS2 catalysts. All possible products were taken into consideration; for example, both HYD and DDS pathways could produce four kinds of products (butadiene, 1-butene, 2-butene, and butane), while the HYD pathway on the S edge of 100% Co-MoS2 catalyst produced three of the same products without butane. From the functional analysis of Co, the Co promoter has changed the original reaction mechanism and related product distribution. The sulfur vacancy on the 50% Co-promoted S edge exhibited the most commendable HDS activity, and 2-butene is obviously improved. Whereas 50% of the Co-promoted Mo edge inhibits the HDS process, Co-doping in the Mo edge could limit its catalysis performance. The generation/regeneration of sulfur vacancies could be the rate-limiting step on the S edge of nonpromoted and Co-promoted MoS2 catalysts; however, it will not be the rate-limiting step on the Mo edge.
coredata.dc:title: Catalysis performance of nonpromoted and co-promoted MoS2 catalysts on a hydrodesulfurization reaction: A DFT study
